Buildings/#Bandstand_tooltip: Generates jugglers and musicians if serviced by the appropriate schools. Must be built at a crossroads.
Buildings/#Bandstand_flavor: People come here to watch the latest juggling tricks and listen to music.
Buildings/#Bandstand_NoJ_NoM: This square never has any shows. It needs jugglers and musicians to liven it up.
Buildings/#Bandstand_J_M: This square offers its community both exciting juggling and music from local musicians.
Buildings/#Bandstand_NoJ_M: This square hosts music for the amusement of the local community. It seeks jugglers to put on a few shows.
Buildings/#Bandstand_J_NoM: This square stages juggling. It could please audiences better if it had musicians to play.
Buildings/#Bandstand_workers_0: This square is dead. With no employees, it provides no leisure services to the local community.
Buildings/#Bandstand_MusicalShow: The musicians will play for another {0} days.
Buildings/#Bandstand_JugglingShow: The current jugglers will amaze for another {0} days.
Buildings/#Booth_tooltip: Generates jugglers if serviced by a juggler school. Must be built on a turn
Buildings/#Booth_flavor: Citizens enjoy clever juggling acts and general nonsense here.
Buildings/#Booth_NoJ: This square never has any shows. It needs real jugglers to provide entertainment for it.
Buildings/#Booth_J: This square is currently staging shows from local jugglers, who usually draw a good audience.
Buildings/#Booth_workers_0: Breezes are the only thing stirring in this square. Without workers, it provides no shows for the locals.
Buildings/#Booth_JugglingShow: The current show will run for another {0} days.
Buildings/#SenetHouse_tooltip: With regular deliveries of beer <sprite name="Beer">, will improve entertainment in the city
Buildings/#SenetHouse_flavor: Games of skill and chance can make or break the fortunes of the players.
Buildings/#SenetHouse_stock_0: This Senet House has players, but a reliable supply of beer would enliven the games.
Buildings/#SenetHouse_workers_1: This Senet House has constant games, much to the delight of the local population.
Buildings/#SenetHouse_workers_0: No one visits this Senet House. Without workers, the local community draws no entertainment from it.
Buildings/#Pavilion_tooltip: Generates jugglers, musicians and dancers if serviced by the appropriate schools. Must be built on a crossroad
Buildings/#Pavilion_flavor: Dancing, music and juggling...what more could a citizen desire?
Buildings/#Pavilion_NoJ_NoM_NoD: This square has no shows. It needs dancers, musicians and jugglers to draw crowds.
Buildings/#Pavilion_J_M_D: This square is in constant motion with dancing, music and juggling greatly delighting the local community.
Buildings/#Pavilion_NoJ_M_D: This square has dancers and musicians for the locals, but some jugglers would be most welcome.
Buildings/#Pavilion_J_NoM_D: This square has dancers and jugglers. It needs musicians to provide complete entertainment.
Buildings/#Pavilion_J_M_NoD: This square has musicians and jugglers, but the music cries out for dancers to complete the show.
Buildings/#Pavilion_J_NoM_NoD: This square has juggling performances, but it needs musicians and dancers to fill the otherwise empty stages.
Buildings/#Pavilion_NoJ_M_NoD: This square has musicians, but no jugglers or dancers.
Buildings/#Pavilion_NoJ_NoM_D: This square has dancers, who would greatly welcome some music. Juggling would be nice, too.
Buildings/#Pavilion_workers_0: This square is closed. With no employees to run it, it is useless as a leisure amenity.
Buildings/#Pavilion_JugglingShow: Juggling will continue for another {0} days.
Buildings/#Pavilion_MusicalShow: The current musical show will run for another {0} days.
Buildings/#Pavilion_DanceShow: The current dance show will run for another {0} days.
Buildings/#Conservatory_tooltip: Sends Musicians to Bandcamps and Pavilions
Buildings/#Conservatory_flavor: Egyptian people are always eager to hear the latest renditions from new musicians.
Buildings/#Conservatory_workers_100: We are pleased to announce that, with full employment, we are training up to four new musicians every month.
Buildings/#Conservatory_workers_75: We are slightly understaffed, and so can train at most two new musicians each month.
Buildings/#Conservatory_workers_50: We only have half of the staff we need and so are only able to train one musician in the coming month.
Buildings/#Conservatory_workers_25: We have so few employees that we will struggle to turn out one new musician over the next two months.
Buildings/#Conservatory_workers_1: I have no staff other than myself. I cannot be expected to work under these conditions! At best, I can train a musician in three months.
Buildings/#Conservatory_workers_0: With no training staff, this school cannot train any new musicians.
Buildings/#DanceSchool_flavor: Dancers delight audiences with graceful and tantalizing new moves.
Buildings/#DanceSchool_workers_100: We are pleased to announce that, with full employment, we can provide up to four new dancers every month.
Buildings/#DanceSchool_workers_75: We are slightly understaffed, and so can only train two new dancers each month at most.
Buildings/#DanceSchool_workers_50: We only have half of the staff we need, so we can only train one dancer in the coming month.
Buildings/#DanceSchool_workers_25: We need instructors so badly that we can barely handle one new dancer over the next two months.
Buildings/#DanceSchool_workers_1: I have no staff other than myself. I cannot be expected to work under these conditions! At best, I can teach one dancer in three months.
Buildings/#DanceSchool_workers_0: With no instructors, this dance school cannot teach any new dancers.
Buildings/#JugglerSchool_tooltip: Sends jugglers to all performances venues: Booths, Bandcamps and Pavilions
Buildings/#JugglerSchool_flavor: New jugglers with inventive new routines are always in demand.
Buildings/#JugglerSchool_workers_100: We are pleased to announce that, with full employment, we train up to four new jugglers every month.
Buildings/#JugglerSchool_workers_75: We are slightly understaffed, and so can produce two new jugglers each month, at most.
Buildings/#JugglerSchool_workers_50: We only have half of the staff we need and so are only able to train one juggler in the coming month.
Buildings/#JugglerSchool_workers_25: We need employees badly. It will be a struggle to turn out one new juggler over the next two months.
Buildings/#JugglerSchool_workers_1: I have no staff other than myself. I cannot be expected to work under these conditions! At best, I can train a juggler in three months.
Buildings/#JugglerSchool_workers_0: This school is deserted. Without mentors in its employ, no new jugglers will be produced.
Buildings/#Gardens_flavor: This pleasant lot gives citizens relief from the noise, heat and dirt of the city with a cool oasis of green space. Everyone wants a garden next door.
Buildings/#Statue_tooltip: Provides desirability to nearby houses, the bigger the statue, the better!
Buildings/#Statue_flavor: Monuments to gods and bygone pharaohs enhance a neighborhood's prestige. People are proud to have statues nearby...and the bigger, the better.
Buildings/#Apothecary_tooltip: Houses visited by apothecaries are better protected from malaria
Buildings/#Apothecary_flavor: Apothecaries improve citizens' health as they make house-calls in the neighborhoods on their route. Wealthy areas want an Apothecary nearby.
Buildings/#Apothecary_workers_0: This Apothecary is not operational, and does nothing for the health of the local community.
Buildings/#Apothecary_workers_1: This Apothecary is operational and provides potions and unguents to the local community.
Buildings/#Mortuary_tooltip: With regular deliveries of linen <sprite name="Linen">, will help prevent diseases and increase health in the city
Buildings/#Mortuary_flavor: Although no one wants to live near one, Mortuaries save lives when disease strikes. The city should have the capacity to embalm all of its dead.
Buildings/#Mortuary_workers_0: This Mortuary is not operational, and cannot prepare departed residents' bodies for the afterlife.
Buildings/#Mortuary_workers_1: This Mortuary is operational and mummifies deceased neighbors quickly and professionally.
Buildings/#Mortuary_stock_0: Without linen, we cannot prepare the dead for their journey through eternity.
Buildings/#Physician_tooltip: Protects citizens from diseases and increases health in the city
Buildings/#Physician_flavor: A pomegranate a day keeps the doctor away, or so the saying goes. Physicians improve health as they make their rounds.
Buildings/#Physician_workers_0: This Physician's office is not operational, and does nothing for community health.
Buildings/#Physician_workers_1: This Physician's office is operational, and the local community is healthy and fit.
Buildings/#Dentist_tooltip: Increases the health of your city. Required for spacious residences
Buildings/#Dentist_flavor: Sand gets into everything, including food. Constant abrasion makes plenty of work for Egyptian dentists.
Buildings/#Dentist_workers_0: This Dentist's office is not operational, and its neighbors' teeth show the lack of care.
Buildings/#Dentist_workers_1: This Dentist's office is operational, and the local community's teeth gleam with pride.
Buildings/#ScribalSchool_tooltip: With regular deliveries of papyrus <sprite name="Papyrus">, will improve education in the city
Buildings/#ScribalSchool_flavor: Children of the wealthy must attend neighborhood schools to learn reading and writing if they are to attain their parents' status.
Buildings/#ScribalSchool_workers_0: This school cannot educate anyone at present. It lacks employees, papyrus, or both.
Buildings/#ScribalSchool_workers_1: This school enables children to escape a life of physical toil as long as it has both employees and papyrus.
Buildings/#Library_tooltip: Also costs 500 papyrus <sprite name="Papyrus"> to build. With regular deliveries of papyrus <sprite name="Papyrus">, will improve education in the city
Buildings/#Library_flavor: Literary works of all kinds are produced and stored here. Scribes insist that Libraries are crucial for an important city.
Buildings/#Library_workers_0: This Library lacks employees, papyrus, or both. It cannot serve the community.
Buildings/#Library_workers_1: As long as this Library has employees and papyrus, it can serve the community.
Buildings/#PoliceStation_tooltip: Curbs crime in the neighborhood. The constable can fight thieves.
Buildings/#PoliceStation_flavor: Police Stations send constables into the city to keep the peace. Civic order is assured when constables patrol the city evenly.
Buildings/#PoliceStation_walker_out: Our constable is out on patrol.
Buildings/#PoliceStation_walker_in: Our constable is preparing for duty.
Buildings/#PoliceStation_workers_100: Currently our duty roster is full. Our constables are always alert to signs of crime.
Buildings/#PoliceStation_workers_75: We are a little short of constables. We have gaps of perhaps a day or two in our coverage.
Buildings/#PoliceStation_workers_50: We are understaffed. Criminals are encouraged by gaps of up to a week in our duty roster.
Buildings/#PoliceStation_workers_25: We have far too few men. Criminals could operate unchecked for up to two weeks at a time.
Buildings/#PoliceStation_workers_1: We are operating with desk staff only. We frequently go a full month without sending a constable out on the streets.
Buildings/#PoliceStation_workers_0: With no staff, this station is little more than a target for vandals.
Buildings/#FortInfantery_tooltip: Where your infantry can rest between battles
Buildings/#FortInfantery_troops: There are currently {0} men stationed at this fort.
Buildings/#FortInfantery_troops_0: There are no men stationed at this fort.
Buildings/#FortInfantery_troops_1: Only one soldier is stationed at this fort.
Buildings/#FortInfantery_upgrade_none: No soldier at this fort is equipped with shields<sprite name="Shields">. Produce some from hides<sprite name="Hides"> to benefit your men.
Buildings/#FortInfantery_upgrade_state: Currently, {0} of your men are equipped with shields<sprite name="Shields">, making them more resilient in battle.
Buildings/#FortInfantery_upgrade_one: Only one man in this fort is currently equipped with a shield<sprite name="Shields">.
Buildings/#FortInfantery_upgrade_full: All the men in this fort are fully equipped with weapons<sprite name="Weapons"> and shields<sprite name="Shields">, you could not find a more efficient company.
Buildings/#FortArchers_tooltip: Where your archers can rest between battles
Buildings/#FortArchers_troops: There are currently {0} archers stationed at this fort.
Buildings/#FortArchers_troops_0: There are no archers at all stationed at this fort.
Buildings/#FortArchers_troops_1: Only one lonely archer is stationed at this fort.
Buildings/#FortArchers_upgrade_none: Archers here are only equipped with simple bows. Produce some Composite Bows<sprite name="CompositeBows"> from wood<sprite name="Wood"> to benefit your men.
Buildings/#FortArchers_upgrade_button: Equip {0} archers with Composite Bows<sprite name="CompositeBows">
Buildings/#FortArchers_upgrade_state: Currently, {0} of your archers are equipped with Composite Bows<sprite name="CompositeBows">, making them more resilient in battle.
Buildings/#FortArchers_upgrade_one: Only one archer in this fort is currently equipped with a composite bow<sprite name="CompositeBows">.
Buildings/#FortArchers_upgrade_full: Every archer at this fort is fully equipped with the best Composite Bows<sprite name="CompositeBows"> in all Egypt!
Buildings/#FortCharioteers_tooltip: Where your charioteers can rest between battles
Buildings/#FortCharioteers_troops: There are currently {0} charioteers stationed at this fort.
Buildings/#FortCharioteers_troops_0: There are no men stationed at this fort.
Buildings/#FortCharioteers_troops_1: Only one charioteer is stationed at this fort.
Buildings/#Fort_curse: This Fort is accursed by Seth, and it will be some time yet before any soldiers dare to venture back here.
Buildings/#Fort_flavor: Forts draw soldiers from the city's Recruiter. A Military Academy would provide better-trained troops.
Buildings/#Fort_full: This fort holds as many soldiers as it can. Build more forts to grow your army!
Buildings/#Gatehouse_tooltip: A segment of wall that allows the passage of a road. Acts as a roadblock
Buildings/#Gatehouse_flavor: Walls need a Gatehouse so that migrants and traders can come and go freely.
Buildings/#Tower_tooltip: Must be built on a thick wall. Occupied by a sentry
Buildings/#Tower_flavor: Build Towers into Walls. When connected to roads, Towers receive guards from the city's Recruiter.
Buildings/#Tower_workers_0: With no workers, we cannot station Tower guards.
Buildings/#Tower_workers_1: Our men are at full strength, alert and ready to repel any threats.
Buildings/#Tower_NoSentry: We have maintenance staff, but we need guards from a Recruiter to defend the city.
Buildings/#Tower_UpgradeStone: This Tower can be upgraded for 1 block of plain stone<sprite name="Plainstone">.
Buildings/#Tower_UpgradeBow: The guard in this Tower can be upgraded with 1 Composite Bow<sprite name="CompositeBows">.
Buildings/#Tower_UpgradeFull: This Tower is now fully upgraded and will protect your city in the most efficient way.
Buildings/#Tower_UpgradeHalf: You already upgraded this Tower once, it could be even more efficient in protecting your city with a second upgrade.
Buildings/#Tower_UpgradeNone: This Tower has not yet been upgraded, it will protect your city but could be more efficient.
Buildings/#OsirisTemple_flavor: Osiris brings fertility to the land and makes the crops grow. Appease him, or prepare to go hungry.
Buildings/#RaTemple_flavor: Merchants know well the value in pleasing Ra. Trade is safer and more profitable with Ra's blessing, and your city's esteem is greater.
Buildings/#PtahTemple_flavor: Laborers and craftsmen worship Ptah to ease their toil. When Ptah is angered, no industry is safe from catastrophe.
Buildings/#SethTemple_flavor: Seth watches over soldiers and encourages valor in combat. No man dares fight without the blessing of Seth.
Buildings/#BastTemple_flavor: When Bast is displeased, nobody's home is safe. Some blame Bast for disease, too.
Buildings/#Bazaar_tooltip: Get food and goods from your granaries and storage yards to distribute them to nearby houses
Buildings/#Bazaar_flavor: Our Bazaars make the Kingdom's bounty available to every nearby citizen. Every home needs Bazaar access, although no one wants to live next door to one.
Buildings/#Bazaar_workers_0: This Bazaar is not operational, and supplies nothing to the local community.
Buildings/#Bazaar_workers_1: This Bazaar is operational and supplies the needs of local homes.
Buildings/#Bazaar_stock_0: This Bazaar has traders, but they are currently looking for food or goods to sell.
Buildings/#Bazaar_TraderIn: The Bazaar trader is here, awaiting food.
Buildings/#Bazaar_TraderOut: The Bazaar trader is out distributing goods.
Buildings/#Bazaar_TraderBack: The Bazaar trader is returning to restock.
Buildings/#Granary_tooltip: Can store every type of food: Chickpeas <sprite name="Chickpeas">, Figs <sprite name="Figs">, Fish <sprite name="Fish">, Game Meat <sprite name="GameMeat">, Grain <sprite name="Grain">, Lettuce <sprite name="Lettuce">, Meat <sprite name="Meat">and Pomegranate <sprite name="Pomegranate">
Buildings/#Granary_flavor: Full Granaries are vital for keeping the people's bellies filled, and help attract new citizens. A Granary can store any type of food.
Buildings/#StorageYard_tooltip: Can store every type of resource your city can produce or trade. Can be used for trade on land
Buildings/#StorageYard_flavor: All manner of goods need storage. Caravans trade at Storage Yards, Docks swap exports for imports at nearby yards, and Bazaars stock up here, too.
Buildings/#StorageYard_Full: WARNING: This Storage Yard is completely full. It cannot accept any more goods.
Buildings/#StorageYard_AlmostFull: WARNING: This Storage Yard is getting full. It can only accept types of goods already stored here. No new commodity types will be checked in at all.
Buildings/#Storage_DeliveryManIn: Our delivery man is ready for new orders.
Buildings/#Storage_DeliveryManOut: Our delivery man is taking goods elsewhere.
Buildings/#Storage_DeliveryManBack: Our delivery man is on his way back.
Buildings/#Storage_DeliveryManGet: Our delivery man is out getting goods
Buildings/#Shipwright_tooltip: Builds boats for your wharfs. Fishing boats are free but military boats will require deliveries of wood <sprite name="Wood">.
Buildings/#Shipwright_flavor: With enough workers, the Shipwright builds military vessels and fishing boats for the city's Wharves. Wood is required to build warships and transport ships; no raw materials are needed to build fishing boats.
Buildings/#Shipwright_idle: There are currently no Wharves demanding any of our vessels.
Buildings/#Shipwright_working: We are building a military vessel or fishing boat to order for a Wharf in the city.
Buildings/#Shipwright_repairing: We are repairing a military vessel.
Buildings/#Shipwright_idle_nowood: We need wood to repair and build military vessels.
Buildings/#Shipwright_working_nowood: A Warship or Transport Wharf has ordered us to build a ship, but we lack the necessary wood.
Buildings/#Shipwright_repairing_nowood: We have ships lined up to be repaired, but no wood with which to repair them.
Buildings/#Dock_tooltip: Trading ships will exchange goods here. Don't forget to build storage yards close by!
Buildings/#Dock_flavor: Trading ships from all over the world moor here to deliver imports and pick up exports. You cannot conduct waterborne trade without Docks.
Buildings/#Dock_docked_workers_0: Without any dockers on staff, we cannot service the docked ship.
Buildings/#Dock_docked_workers_1: We are servicing the docked ship. With so few dock workers, though, this could take a long time.
Buildings/#Dock_docked_workers_50: We are servicing the docked ship, although this will take a little longer than it would if we were fully staffed.
Buildings/#Dock_docked_workers_100: With full employment, we can service the docked ship quickly and efficiently.
Buildings/#Dock_empty_workers_0: Any ship that moors here will find no workers to load or unload its cargo.
Buildings/#Dock_empty_workers_1: The few dockers employed here would take a long time to load and unload any ships that arrive in port.
Buildings/#Dock_empty_workers_50: We are understaffed, so it will take a little longer than normal to load and unload any ships that arrive in port.
Buildings/#Dock_empty_workers_100: With full employment, our dockers are just waiting for their ship to come in.
Buildings/#FishingWharf_tooltip: Once the shipwright has sent this wharf its fishing boat, it will produce fish <sprite name="Fish"> from the nearest fishing point
Buildings/#FishingWharf_flavor: Boats sail here from the Shipwright to take on crews and begin fishing local waters. Each Wharf can service one fishing boat.
Buildings/#FishingWharf_noboat: We are currently waiting for a Shipwright to build us a fishing boat.
Buildings/#FishingWharf_tofishingpoint: Our fishing boat is sailing out to the fishing grounds.
Buildings/#FishingWharf_fishing: Our boat is at the fishing grounds now, hauling in fish.
Buildings/#FishingWharf_fromshipwright: Our boat is sailing to the Wharf now.
Buildings/#FishingWharf_dockedboat: We are re-stocking our fishing boat for another outbound voyage.
Buildings/#FishingWharf_fromfishingpoint: Our fishing boat is sailing back from the fishing grounds with its catch.
Buildings/#FishingWharf_nofishingpoint: Our fishermen hope that someone discovers fishing grounds in this area someday. They can't earn much of a living with the waters depleted.
Buildings/#FishingWharf_disabled: Your Overseer of Commerce ordered a halt to fishing.
Buildings/#FishingWharf_plague: Our fishing boat is not going out into that polluted water!
Buildings/#PersonalMansion_tooltip: Your own home! Allows you to draw a salary. Must be built on a grassy area
Buildings/#FamilyMansion_tooltip: A beautiful mansion for you and your family. Allows you to draw a salary. Must be built on a grassy area
Buildings/#DynastyMansion_tooltip: One of the most incredible residences in all of Egypt, and it's yours! Allows you to draw a salary. Must be built on a grassy area
Buildings/#Mansion_flavor: Your home is one of the city's most desirable addresses. Your Mansion gives you the authority to draw a salary.
Buildings/#ArchitectPost_tooltip: Sends an architect roaming the streets to prevent buildings from collapsing
Buildings/#ArchitectPost_flavor: Egyptian architects are the most advanced the world has ever known. Their vigilance prevents buildings from collapsing.
Buildings/#ArchitectPost_Architect_Out: Our architect is hard at work.
Buildings/#ArchitectPost_Architect_In: Our architect is preparing to depart.
Buildings/#ArchitectPost_workers_100: Currently we have no down time. Our architects are constantly out inspecting and repairing the city's larger buildings.
Buildings/#ArchitectPost_workers_75: We have a day or two before our overworked architects are back out on the streets.
Buildings/#ArchitectPost_workers_50: We are understaffed, so we have a week's wait before our returning architects go back on duty.
Buildings/#ArchitectPost_workers_25: We are badly understaffed and have a two-week gap between each architect's rounds.
Buildings/#ArchitectPost_workers_1: We are operating on a skeleton staff. We can barely field one architect each month.
Buildings/#ArchitectPost_workers_0: With no architects on staff, the neighborhood is at the mercy of shifting sands.
Buildings/#VillagePalace_tooltip: Stores most of the city treasure. Allows you to collect tax. Must be built on a grassy area
Buildings/#TownPalace_tooltip: A proper Palace for your thriving town that stores most of the city treasure. Allows you to collect tax. Must be built on a grassy area.
Buildings/#CityPalace_tooltip: This humongous Palace stores most of the city treasure. Allows you to collect tax. Must be built on a grassy area.
Buildings/#Palace_flavor: The Palace is among your city's most desirable buildings and the cornerstone of the city economy. It turns gold nuggets to debens and stores some of the city's funds.
Buildings/#TaxCollector_tooltip: Allows you to tax your citizens. Requires a working Palace
Buildings/#TaxCollector_flavor: Although not the most popular workers in the city, tax collectors make our great Kingdom and all the benefits that flow to us possible.
Buildings/#TaxCollector_Collector_Out: Our collector is out auditing the locals' accounts.
Buildings/#TaxCollector_Collector_In: Our collector is preparing to depart.
Buildings/#TaxCollector_workers_100: Currently working with complete efficiency, our collectors ensure that all due taxes on their routes are paid.
Buildings/#TaxCollector_workers_75: We have a day or two of idle time before returning collectors go back out on the streets.
Buildings/#TaxCollector_workers_50: We are understaffed, and have a week's wait before any collectors return to duty.
Buildings/#TaxCollector_workers_25: We are badly understaffed and go two weeks between collection patrols.
Buildings/#TaxCollector_workers_1: With so few people in this office, local citizens can evade many of their tax bills.
Buildings/#TaxCollector_workers_0: With no collection staff, this office contributes nothing to the city treasury.
Buildings/#TaxCollector_NoPalace: Your city needs a Palace before you can collect taxes.
Buildings/#TaxCollector_NoWorkingPalace: Your city needs a working Palace in order to collect taxes.
Buildings/#WaterLift_tooltip: Pump water from the Nile into Irrigation Ditches to irrigate your farms.
Buildings/#WaterLift_flavor: This Water Lift can pump large volumes of water when Irrigation Ditches are connected to its front or back sluices.
Buildings/#WaterLift_workers_0: This Water Lift is not working. Ask your Overseer of the Workers to assign more workers to Water Services.
Buildings/#WaterLift_floodplain_unconnec: This Water Lift needs to be adjacent to water, or connected by an Irrigation Ditch to a working Water Lift, before it will function.
Buildings/#WaterSupply_tooltips: Sends a water carrier to deliver drinking water to your houses. Must be built on a grassy area.
Buildings/#WaterSupply_flavor: Water carriers get clean water from this desirable source, and improve health and happiness as they deliver it to houses on their routes.
Buildings/#WaterSupply_workers_100: Our staff continuously carry clean water to the local populace.
Buildings/#WaterSupply_workers_75: We are a little short of water carriers. We have gaps of perhaps a day or two in our coverage.
Buildings/#WaterSupply_workers_50: We are understaffed, and have dangerous gaps of up to a week in our water delivery cycle.
Buildings/#WaterSupply_workers_25: We have far too few workers. Sometimes, no water is delivered for up to two weeks at a time.
Buildings/#WaterSupply_workers_1: We are operating with a skeleton staff only. We frequently go a full month without delivering any water.
Buildings/#WaterSupply_workers_0: With no delivery staff, this facility could just as well be a dry hole in the ground.
Buildings/#Well_tooltips: Provides water within a 2-tile radius. No workers needed. Must be built on a grassy area.
Buildings/#Well_flavor: Citizens without clean water deliveries can draw water from Wells, but Well-water neighborhoods are not the healthiest or most desirable places to live.
Buildings/#Well_unneeded: This well is unneeded. All the houses it serves get deliveries from a Water Supply.
Buildings/#Well_nohouses: This well's water is going to waste, as there are no houses within its service range.
Buildings/#BurningRuin_flavor: Fire marshals could not get here in time to save the building. When the fires burn out, only rubble will be left on this site.
Buildings/#GrainFarm_tooltip: Produces grain <sprite name="Grain"> and 100 units of straw <sprite name="Straw">. Harvest in May and January when built on a meadow
Buildings/#GrainFarm_flavor: Grain must be stored in Granaries to feed your people, or in Storage Yards if it is for export.
Buildings/#GrainFarm_disabled: Your Overseer of Commerce ordered a halt to grain farming.
Buildings/#GrainFarm_workers_0: This farm has no workers. Even weeds struggle to grow here.
Buildings/#GrainFarm_workers_100: This farm has all the workers it needs. It gets maximum yield, given its current fertility.
Buildings/#GrainFarm_workers_75: This farm could be more productive if it had more workers.
Buildings/#GrainFarm_workers_50: This farm is understaffed. Its workers don't grow as much food as they could.
Buildings/#GrainFarm_workers_25: There are very few farmers working here. Grain production is scanty as a result.
Buildings/#GrainFarm_workers_1: With hardly any workers at this farm, it will produce very little grain this season.
Buildings/#Farm_Plagued: This farm's land was blighted by the recent swarm of locusts, and will take some time to recover.
Buildings/#GrainFarm_harvest: The next grain harvest is in {[Month]}.
Buildings/#LettuceFarm_tooltip: Produces lettuce <sprite name="Lettuce">. Harvest in April when built on a meadow
Buildings/#LettuceFarm_flavor: Lettuce contributes to the balanced diet your people need for happiness and health. Granaries store lettuce for local consumption, and Storage Yards take surpluses for export.
Buildings/#LettuceFarm_disabled: The Overseer of Commerce decreed that lettuce farming should cease.
Buildings/#LettuceFarm_workers_0: This farm has no workers. Nothing has been planted.
Buildings/#LettuceFarm_workers_100: This farm has all the workers it needs. It grows as much lettuce as its fertility allows.
Buildings/#LettuceFarm_workers_75: This farm is working below maximum capacity, so its crop is smaller than it could be.
Buildings/#LettuceFarm_workers_50: This farm is understaffed. Its lettuce heads are smaller and fewer than they could be.
Buildings/#LettuceFarm_workers_25: There are very few farmers working here. The lettuce harvest will suffer greatly for it.
Buildings/#LettuceFarm_workers_1: With almost no farmers to tend the crop, this will not be a banner year for lettuce.
Buildings/#LettuceFarm_harvest: The next lettuce harvest is in {[Month]}.
Buildings/#PomegranateFarm_tooltip: Produces pomegranate <sprite name="Pomegranate">. Harvest in June and November when built on a meadow
Buildings/#PomegranateFarm_flavor: Pomegranates enhance the balanced diet people need for health and happiness. Granaries store pomegranates for local consumption, and Storage Yards can export surpluses.
Buildings/#PomegranateFarm_disabled: Pomegranate farming has ceased, by order of the Overseer of Commerce.
Buildings/#PomegranateFarm_workers_0: This orchard has no workers, and the trees are fruitless and gnarled.
Buildings/#PomegranateFarm_workers_100: This orchard has all the workers it needs. The trees bear as much fruit as the land's fertility allows.
Buildings/#PomegranateFarm_workers_75: This orchard is working below maximum capacity, so the crop this year is a bit lighter than it should be.
Buildings/#PomegranateFarm_workers_50: This orchard is understaffed. It produces fewer pomegranates than it could.
Buildings/#PomegranateFarm_workers_25: Very few people work at this orchard. The pomegranate harvest will be small.
Buildings/#PomegranateFarm_workers_1: With hardly any workers at this orchard, the pomegranate crop will be quite disappointing.
Buildings/#PomegranateFarm_harvest: The next pomegranate harvest is in {[Month]}.
Buildings/#FlaxFarm_tooltip: Produces flax <sprite name="Flax">. Harvest in December when built on a meadow
Buildings/#FlaxFarm_flavor: Flax goes to a Weaver, who processes the fibers and weaves them into linen for Mortuaries to use in embalming, or for export.
Buildings/#FlaxFarm_disabled: Your Overseer of Commerce ordered a halt to flax growing.
Buildings/#FlaxFarm_workers_0: This farm has no workers. No flax can grow here.
Buildings/#FlaxFarm_workers_100: This farm has all the workers it needs. The fields are carpeted with blue flax flowers.
Buildings/#FlaxFarm_workers_75: This farm is working below maximum capacity. Flax production could be better with more workers.
Buildings/#FlaxFarm_workers_50: This farm is understaffed. Flax plants aren't as dense or as sturdy as they could be.
Buildings/#FlaxFarm_workers_25: There are very few people working here. The flax harvest will suffer as a result.
Buildings/#FlaxFarm_workers_1: With hardly any workers on this farm, the ground is mostly barren.
Buildings/#FlaxFarm_harvest: The next flax harvest is in {[Month]}.
Buildings/#ReedGatherer_tooltip: Dispatches 5 gatherers to look for reeds <sprite name="Reeds"> in the marshes
Buildings/#ReedGatherer_flavor: Reed gatherers venture from here into the marshes to collect reeds for papyrus, without which education would be impossible.
Buildings/#ReedGatherer_disabled: Reed harvesting has ceased, by command of the Overseer of Commerce.
Buildings/#ReedGatherer_workers_0: This place has no workers to gather reeds.
Buildings/#ReedGatherer_workers_100: This place has all the workers it needs. No reed is safe.
Buildings/#ReedGatherer_workers_75: This place is below its labor potential, so reed gathering is slowed somewhat.
Buildings/#ReedGatherer_workers_50: This place is understaffed, so reed cutting is slow going.
Buildings/#ReedGatherer_workers_25: Very few people work here, and few reeds are being cut.
Buildings/#ReedGatherer_workers_1: With so few gatherers employed here, almost no reeds are harvested.
Buildings/#CattleRanch_tooltip: Produces meat <sprite name="Meat"> out of straw <sprite name="Straw">
Buildings/#CattleRanch_flavor: Well-fed citizens want meat in their diet. Meat can be kept in Granaries for local consumption, or taken to Storage Yards for export.
Buildings/#CattleRanch_disabled: By decree of the Overseer of Commerce, cattle ranching has ceased.
Buildings/#CattleRanch_workers_0: This ranch has no workers. All of the animals have escaped or died.
Buildings/#CattleRanch_workers_100: This ranch has all the workers it needs. With straw, it can yield ample meat.
Buildings/#CattleRanch_workers_75: This ranch needs to hire more workers if it is to produce meat efficiently.
Buildings/#CattleRanch_workers_50: This farm is understaffed. It cannot reach its potential output.
Buildings/#CattleRanch_workers_25: Very few people work at this ranch. Its potential meat production is low.
Buildings/#CattleRanch_workers_1: With hardly any workers, this ranch can raise very few cattle.
Buildings/#PlainStoneQuarry_tooltip: Needs to be placed near rocks. Produces plain stone <sprite name="Plainstone">
Buildings/#PlainStoneQuarry_flavor: Cut plain stone from the earth here. With monuments rising all across Egypt, you can usually find a buyer for good building stone, even if you have no use for it yourself.
Buildings/#PlainStoneQuarry_disabled: The Overseer of Commerce commanded a halt to quarrying.
Buildings/#PlainStoneQuarry_workers_0: This quarry has no workers to cut rock from the earth.
Buildings/#PlainStoneQuarry_workers_100: This quarry has all the workers it needs, and produces many tons of plain stone.
Buildings/#PlainStoneQuarry_workers_75: This quarry is working below maximum capacity due to a small shortage of workers.
Buildings/#PlainStoneQuarry_workers_50: This quarry is understaffed, and takes longer to produce stone blocks than it should.
Buildings/#PlainStoneQuarry_workers_25: There are very few people working at this quarry. Production is very slow as a result.
Buildings/#PlainStoneQuarry_workers_1: With hardly any workers at this quarry, production is at a virtual standstill. It will produce little over the coming year.
Buildings/#LimestoneQuarry_tooltip: Needs to be placed near rocks. Produces limestone <sprite name="Limestone">
Buildings/#LimestoneQuarry_flavor: Cut fine limestone for use in monument construction or for export.
Buildings/#LimestoneQuarry_disabled: Your Overseer of Commerce ordered a halt to limestone quarrying.
Buildings/#LimestoneQuarry_workers_0: This quarry has no workers, and thus produces no limestone.
Buildings/#LimestoneQuarry_workers_100: This quarry has all the workers it needs, and produces as much limestone as possible.
Buildings/#LimestoneQuarry_workers_75: This quarry is working below maximum capacity. Production could be greater with more workers.
Buildings/#LimestoneQuarry_workers_50: This building is understaffed. It takes longer than it should to cut blocks of limestone.
Buildings/#LimestoneQuarry_workers_25: Very few people work in this building. Production is much too slow as a result.
Buildings/#LimestoneQuarry_workers_1: With hardly any workers here, limestone production is almost nonexistent.
Buildings/#WoodCutter_tooltip: Dispatches 3 tree-cutters to gather as much wood <sprite name="Wood"> as possible
Buildings/#WoodCutter_flavor: Wood has many uses ranging from monument construction to shipbuilding, and is in great demand throughout the Kingdom.
Buildings/#WoodCutter_disabled: Tree cutting has ceased, by order of the Overseer of Commerce.
Buildings/#WoodCutter_workers_0: This facility has no workers, and contributes nothing to the city's economy.
Buildings/#WoodCutter_workers_100: This building has all the workers it needs. It harvests wood with maximum efficiency.
Buildings/#WoodCutter_workers_75: This Wood Cutter is not fully staffed, and wood production is lower than it could be.
Buildings/#WoodCutter_workers_50: This industry is understaffed, and takes longer to cut wood than it should.
Buildings/#WoodCutter_workers_25: Very few people work at this yard. Wood production is very slow as a result.
Buildings/#WoodCutter_workers_1: With hardly any tree-cutters, wood output is at a virtual standstill here.
Buildings/#ClayPit_tooltip: To be placed near water. Produces clay <sprite name="Clay">
Buildings/#ClayPit_flavor: Mine clay for trade, or to supply potters. People find endless uses for pottery, and you can often trade it profitably with other cities.
Buildings/#ClayPit_disabled: Your Overseer of Commerce stopped clay digging.
Buildings/#ClayPit_workers_0: This pit has no workers to dig clay.
Buildings/#ClayPit_workers_100: This pit has all the workers it needs, and produces large amounts of clay.
Buildings/#ClayPit_workers_75: This pit is working below maximum capacity. Clay production will be slightly slower as a result.
Buildings/#ClayPit_workers_50: This pit is understaffed, and is taking longer to produce clay than it should.
Buildings/#ClayPit_workers_25: So few people work at this pit that clay production is extremely slow.
Buildings/#ClayPit_workers_1: With hardly any diggers at this pit, it will produce very little clay over the coming year.
Buildings/#Brewery_tooltip: Produces beer <sprite name="Beer"> out of barley <sprite name="Barley">
Buildings/#Brewery_flavor: Brewers turn barley into beer, without which the Senet Houses would be empty and the city's festivals boring. Beer is a widely demanded trade commodity.
Buildings/#Brewery_disabled: An edict from the Overseer of Commerce ordered a halt to brewing.
Buildings/#Brewery_workers_0: This Brewery has no employees. There will be no beer from here.
Buildings/#Brewery_workers_100: With a full complement of employees, this Brewery works at top speed to slake Egypt's thirst.
Buildings/#Brewery_workers_75: This Brewery is working below maximum capacity. Beer output is slightly slower than it could be.
Buildings/#Brewery_workers_50: This Brewery is understaffed, and takes much longer to produce beer than it should.
Buildings/#Brewery_workers_25: Very few people work at this Brewery. Beer production is very slow as a result.
Buildings/#Brewery_workers_1: With hardly any brewers on staff, this Brewery will produce almost no beer over the coming year.
Buildings/#Brewery_stock_0: This Brewery cannot make beer until it receives a delivery of barley from a Storage Yard or a farm.
Buildings/#Weaver_tooltip: Produces linen <sprite name="Linen"> out of flax <sprite name="Flax">
Buildings/#Weaver_flavor: Here flax is processed into linen, which Mortuaries need for embalming. Linen may also be profitably traded.
Buildings/#Weaver_disabled: Your Overseer of Commerce decreed that linen production be wrapped up.
Buildings/#Weaver_workers_0: This Weaver has no workers, and so cannot produce any linen at all.
Buildings/#Weaver_workers_100: This Weaver is fully staffed, and produces ample high-quality linen.
Buildings/#Weaver_workers_75: This Weaver could use more workers to reach its full potential for linen production.
Buildings/#Weaver_workers_50: This Weaver is understaffed, and produces linen more slowly than it should.
Buildings/#Weaver_workers_25: Very few people work at this Weaver. Linen production is slow as a result.
Buildings/#Weaver_workers_1: With hardly any employees, this Weaver can produce almost no linen over the coming year.
Buildings/#Weaver_stock_0: This workshop will produce no linen without a shipment of flax, whether from a Storage Yard or a farm.
Buildings/#Weaponsmith_tooltip: Produces weapons <sprite name="Weapons"> out of copper <sprite name="Copper">
Buildings/#Weaponsmith_flavor: Armorers transform copper into spears, which you may trade at a handsome profit or use to equip your own companies.
Buildings/#Weaponsmith_disabled: Your Overseer of Commerce ordered a halt to weapon production.
Buildings/#Weaponsmith_workers_0: This Weaponsmith has no employees, and will therefore produce no weapons.
Buildings/#Weaponsmith_workers_100: This workshop has all the employees it needs, and produces as many weapons as possible.
Buildings/#Weaponsmith_workers_75: This Weaponsmith is not fully staffed, so weapon production is slightly slower than it could be.
Buildings/#Weaponsmith_workers_50: This workshop is understaffed. It takes longer to produce weapons than it should.
Buildings/#Weaponsmith_workers_25: There are very few people working at this Weaponsmith. Weapon production is very slow.
Buildings/#Weaponsmith_workers_1: With hardly any employees, this Weaponsmith contributes very few weapons to the city's efforts.
Buildings/#Weaponsmith_stock_0: This Weaponsmith needs copper, from a Storage Yard or a Copper Mine, to produce weapons.
Buildings/#Jeweler_tooltip: Produces jewelry <sprite name="Jewelry"> out of gems <sprite name="Gems">
Buildings/#Jeweler_flavor: The craftsmen here turn gemstones into jewelry (a luxury good). Some citizens want jewelry for themselves, and you can often export any surplus, although it is seldom worth much.
Buildings/#Jeweler_disabled: The Overseer of Commerce commands a halt to jewelry production.
Buildings/#Jeweler_workers_0: This Jeweler has no employees, and is not producing anything.
Buildings/#Jeweler_workers_100: This facility is at full employment, and makes as much jewelry as possible.
Buildings/#Jeweler_workers_75: This facility has some job openings. Jewelry production will improve when they are filled.
Buildings/#Jeweler_workers_50: This facility is understaffed, and takes longer to produce jewelry than it should.
Buildings/#Jeweler_workers_25: Very few craftsmen work here. Jewelry production is very slow as a result.
Buildings/#Jeweler_workers_1: With hardly any craftsmen, this Jeweler will produce few luxury goods over the coming year.
Buildings/#Jeweler_stock_0: This workshop needs a shipment of gems from a Storage Yard or a Gemstone Mine to produce jewelry.
Buildings/#Potter_tooltip: Produces pottery <sprite name="Pottery"> out of clay <sprite name="Clay">
Buildings/#Potter_flavor: Here, potters mould clay into pots that citizens use for storing commodities. Trade pottery, or let your Bazaars distribute it so that people can build better housing.
Buildings/#Potter_disabled: Pottery production has ceased, by order of the Overseer of Commerce.
Buildings/#Potter_workers_0: This Potter has no employees. It will not turn out a single pot.
Buildings/#Potter_workers_100: This Potter has all the employees it needs, and produces as much pottery as possible.
Buildings/#Potter_workers_75: This Potter has some job openings. Pottery production will suffer slightly as a result.
Buildings/#Potter_workers_50: This workshop is understaffed, and it takes longer to produce pottery than it should.
Buildings/#Potter_workers_25: Very few people work here, so pottery production is very slow.
Buildings/#Potter_workers_1: With hardly any employees, this Potter will produce almost no pottery over the coming year.
Buildings/#Potter_stock_0: This workshop needs clay delivered to it, from a Storage Yard or a Clay Pit, to produce pottery.
Buildings/#MilitaryAcademy_tooltip: Train recruits before they join a fort
Buildings/#MilitaryAcademy_flavor: When new soldiers finish their basic training at the Recruiter, they seek to improve in quality and capability at this academy, but cannot until it receives its full quota of staff.
Buildings/#MilitaryAcademy_workers_0: With no staff, we cannot polish the skills of the city's new soldiers. They will have to go straight to their Forts and hope for the best.
Buildings/#MilitaryAcademy_workers_1: We give green soldiers from the city's Recruiter the extra edge they need to excel in today's Egyptian army.
Buildings/#Recruiter_tooltip: Recruits soldiers among your citizens. Needs weapons <sprite name="Weapons"> for infantry and chariots <sprite name="Chariots"> for charioteers
Buildings/#Recruiter_flavor: No one can join the Egyptian army without first passing through here; it's the city's training school for new recruits.
Buildings/#Recruiter_workers_0: With no staff, we cannot train a single new recruit. Seth help us in times of war!
Buildings/#Recruiter_notneeded: We are not currently training any recruits, as we have no requests from city Forts or Towers for any new men.
Buildings/#Recruiter_nostock_workers_100: We can train new archers quickly enough, but we need weapons to add any infantry or chariots to the city's battalion.
Buildings/#Recruiter_nostock_workers_66: We are lacking employees, so we can only train soldiers at a reduced rate. Without stored weapons, we can't train infantry or charioteers.
Buildings/#Recruiter_nostock_workers_33: We are understaffed and out of weapons! We can train archers, but only slowly.
Buildings/#Recruiter_nostock_workers_1: With a skeleton staff and no supply of weapons, we can just barely train the occasional archer.
Buildings/#Recruiter_workers_100: We train new soldiers at maximum efficiency, and we have the weapons to train any type of soldier.
Buildings/#Recruiter_workers_66: We train new soldiers at reduced speed due to lack of staff, although we do have the weapons to train any type of soldier.
Buildings/#Recruiter_workers_33: We are understaffed and training new soldiers slowly, but we have the weapons to train any type of soldier.
Buildings/#Recruiter_workers_1: With a skeleton staff, we are training new soldiers extremely slowly, even though we have the weapons to train any type of soldier.
Buildings/#Recruiter_CompositeBowsStored: Composite Bows<sprite name="CompositeBows"> Stored: {0} units.[i2p_One]Composite Bow<sprite name="CompositeBows"> Stored: {0} unit.
Buildings/#Recruiter_ShieldsStored: Shields<sprite name="Shields"> Stored: {0} units.[i2p_One]Shield<sprite name="Shields"> Stored: {0} unit.
Buildings/#Plaza_tooltip: To be placed on paved roads to improve desirability
Buildings/#Plaza_flavor: Plazas make ordinary paved roads more desirable, without affecting traffic.
Buildings/#IrrigationDitch_tooltip: When connected to a working water lift, irrigates nearby farms
Buildings/#IrrigationDitch_working: This Irrigation Ditch moves water to help fertilize farmland
Buildings/#IrrigationDitch_nsource: This Irrigation Ditch is not transporting water to less fertile areas, as it has no source of water from which to draw.
Buildings/#HuntingLodge_tooltip: Dispatches 3 hunters to gather game meat <sprite name="GameMeat"> from prey. Also produces hides<sprite name="Hides"> from antelopes.
Buildings/#HuntingLodge_flavor: Hunters based here track and hunt local wildlife. The Hunting Lodge then distributes game meat to local Storage Yards or Granaries.
Buildings/#HuntingLodge_disabled: The Overseer of Commerce decreed that hunting should cease.
Buildings/#HuntingLodge_workers_0: This lodge has no workers. The hunt is canceled.
Buildings/#HuntingLodge_workers_100: This lodge has all the workers it needs. The hunters are stalking every herd they can find.
Buildings/#HuntingLodge_workers_75: This lodge is working below maximum capacity. Food collection will be slower as a result.
Buildings/#HuntingLodge_workers_50: This lodge is understaffed, and it takes longer to collect meat than it should.
Buildings/#HuntingLodge_workers_25: Very few people work here. Meat collection is slow, indeed.
Buildings/#HuntingLodge_workers_1: With hardly any hunters working here, prey animals cavort unmolested. It could be a very hungry dry season...
Buildings/#HuntingLodge_HuntersOut: This lodge's hunters are out seeking prey.
Buildings/#HuntingLodge_DistantPreyPoint: It takes too long for meat to get back to the lodge. Try putting it closer to wildlife.
Buildings/#Roadblock_tooltip: Restricts walkers' patrol routes. Must be built on a road
Buildings/#Roadblock_flavor: Place roadblocks to restrict walkers' patrol routes. People with specific destinations (like delivery men or Bazaar buyers) can pass freely.
Buildings/#OsirisShrine_tooltip: Improves Osiris' mood. Can be built a tile away from the road
Buildings/#OsirisShrine_flavor: Osiris brings fertility to the land and makes the crops grow. Appease him, or prepare to go hungry.
Buildings/#RaShrine_tooltip: Improves Ra's mood. Can be built a tile away from the road
Buildings/#RaShrine_flavor: Merchants know well the value in pleasing Ra. Trade is safer and more profitable with Ra's blessing, and your city's esteem is greater.
Buildings/#PtahShrine_tooltip: Improves Ptah's mood. Can be built a tile away from the road
Buildings/#PtahShrine_flavor: Laborers and craftsmen worship Ptah to ease their toil. When Ptah is angered, no industry is safe from catastrophe.
Buildings/#SethShrine_tooltip: Improves Seth's mood. Can be built a tile away from the road
Buildings/#SethShrine_flavor: Seth watches over soldiers and encourages valor in combat. No man dares fight without the blessing of Seth.
Buildings/#BastShrine_tooltip: Improves Bast's mood. Can be built a tile away from the road
Buildings/#BastShrine_flavor: When Bast is displeased, nobody's home is safe. Some blame Bast for disease, too.
Buildings/#GoldMine_tooltip: Needs to be placed near veins to produce gold <sprite name="Gold"> that is transformed into debens <sprite name="Deben"> at the palace
Buildings/#GoldMine_flavor: Mining gold is the most direct way to fill your city's treasury. Lucky is the city that has this precious resource, for its wealth is assured.
Buildings/#GoldMine_disabled: The Overseer of Commerce commanded an end to gold mining.
Buildings/#GoldMine_workers_0: This mine has no workers. No ore whatsoever can be extracted.
Buildings/#GoldMine_workers_100: This mine has all the workers it needs, and produces a small fortune in gold.
Buildings/#GoldMine_workers_75: This mine is working below maximum capacity. It would yield more gold if there were more miners.
Buildings/#GoldMine_workers_50: This mine is understaffed. It produces less gold than it could.
Buildings/#GoldMine_workers_25: Very few people work here. Gold output is rather anemic.
Buildings/#GoldMine_workers_1: With hardly any workers here, mining has nearly stopped. Very little gold will come of this.
Buildings/#GemstoneMine_tooltip: Needs to be placed near rocks to produce gems <sprite name="Gems">
Buildings/#GemstoneMine_flavor: Mine gems for export, or to produce jewelry, your city's basic luxury good.
Buildings/#GemstoneMine_disabled: Your Overseer of Commerce ruled that the city has enough gems, and halted mining.
Buildings/#GemstoneMine_workers_0: This mine has no workers. Precious stones remain locked forever in the rock.
Buildings/#GemstoneMine_workers_100: This mine has all the workers it needs, and produces glittering mounds of gems.
Buildings/#GemstoneMine_workers_75: This mine has some job openings, and gem production is less efficient than it could be.
Buildings/#GemstoneMine_workers_50: This mine is understaffed. It produces considerably fewer gems than it could.
Buildings/#GemstoneMine_workers_25: Very few miners work here. Teasing gems from rock is very slow going indeed.
Buildings/#GemstoneMine_workers_1: With hardly any workers here, almost no gems are being mined.
Buildings/#Firehouse_tooltip: Prevents buildings from catching fire. The fire marshal can stop ongoing fires
Buildings/#Firehouse_flavor: Firehouses send marshals into the city to prevent fires, and to fight those that do break out.
Buildings/#Firehouse_Marshal_Out: Our marshal is patrolling the streets.
Buildings/#Firehouse_Marshal_In: Our marshal is preparing for duty.
Buildings/#Firehouse_workers_100: Currently our duty roster is full. Our marshals are always out there, sniffing out evidence of fire.
Buildings/#Firehouse_workers_75: We are a little short of marshals. We have gaps of perhaps a day or two in our coverage.
Buildings/#Firehouse_workers_50: We are understaffed. There are delays of up to a week in fire prevention patrols.
Buildings/#Firehouse_workers_25: We have far too few men. Often, no marshals leave the Firehouse for up to two weeks at a time.
Buildings/#Firehouse_workers_1: We are operating with desk staff only. We frequently go a full month without sending a marshal out on the streets.
Buildings/#Firehouse_workers_0: With no staff, this Firehouse is little more than a fire waiting to happen.
Buildings/#Wall_tooltip: Necessary to build towers, terrible for desirability
Buildings/#Wall_flavor: While not offering protections on their own, the towers you build on them can help win battles.
Buildings/#CarpentersGuild_tooltip: Needed to build some monuments. Requires deliveries of wood <sprite name="Wood">
Buildings/#CarpentersGuild_flavor: Carpenters gather here to swap stories and tips about their profession, find work assignments and hammer out their problems.
Buildings/#CarpentersGuild_disabled: This guild has been shuttered by your Overseer of Commerce
Buildings/#CarpentersGuild_workers_0: This guild has no employees. Carpentry services are not available.
Buildings/#CarpentersGuild_workers_100: This guild has all the employees it needs. Carpenters can work with maximal efficiency.
Buildings/#CarpentersGuild_workers_75: This guild is working below maximum capacity. Work will be slightly slower as a result.
Buildings/#CarpentersGuild_workers_50: This guild is understaffed, and supplies fewer carpenters than it could.
Buildings/#CarpentersGuild_workers_25: Very few people work here. There is a considerable wait for a carpenter's services.
Buildings/#CarpentersGuild_workers_1: With hardly any employees at this guild, it seems to take forever for a carpenter to show up.
Buildings/#CarpentersGuild_stocks_0: This workshop needs wood delivered to it.
Buildings/#BricklayersGuild_tooltip: Sends bricklayers to work on monuments
Buildings/#BricklayersGuild_flavor: Bricklayers gather here to swap stories and tips about their profession, find work assignments and lay plans for the future.
Buildings/#BricklayersGuild_disabled: This guild has been shut down by your Overseer of Commerce
Buildings/#BricklayersGuild_workers_0: This guild has no employees. No bricks can be laid.
Buildings/#BricklayersGuild_workers_100: This guild has all the employees it needs. Bricklayers can work with maximal efficiency.
Buildings/#BricklayersGuild_workers_75: This guild is working below maximum capacity. Work will be slightly slower as a result.
Buildings/#BricklayersGuild_workers_50: This guild is understaffed, and supplies fewer bricklayers than it could.
Buildings/#BricklayersGuild_workers_25: Very few people work here. There is a substantial wait for bricklaying services.
Buildings/#BricklayersGuild_workers_1: With hardly any employees at this guild, it seems to take forever for a bricklayer to show up.
Buildings/#BricklayersGuild_info: This guild provides skilled workers for monument construction. It does not need its own supply of bricks.
Buildings/#StonemasonsGuild_tooltip: Sends stonemasons to work on monuments
Buildings/#StonemasonsGuild_flavor: Stonemasons meet here to swap stories and tips about their profession, find work assignments and hew plans for the future.
Buildings/#StonemasonsGuild_disabled: This guild has been shut down by your Overseer of Commerce
Buildings/#StonemasonsGuild_workers_0: This guild has no employees. Stonecarving is not possible.
Buildings/#StonemasonsGuild_workers_100: This guild has all the employees it needs. Stonemasons can work with maximal efficiency.
Buildings/#StonemasonsGuild_workers_75: This guild is working below maximum capacity. Work will be slightly slower as a result.
Buildings/#StonemasonsGuild_workers_50: This guild is understaffed, and provides fewer stonemasons than it could.
Buildings/#StonemasonsGuild_workers_25: Very few people work here. There is a lengthy wait for stonemasonry.
Buildings/#StonemasonsGuild_workers_1: With hardly any employees at this guild, it seems to take forever for a stonemason to report for duty.
Buildings/#StonemasonsGuild_info: This guild provides skilled workers for monument construction. It does not need its own supply of stone.
Buildings/#TransportWharf_tooltip: Transports troops to battlefields far away
Buildings/#TransportWharf_flavor: Transport ships, built by Shipwrights, moor here between assignments. Your battalion needs transport to navigate the Nile.
Buildings/#WarshipWharf_tooltip: A warship to face the battles to come
Buildings/#WarshipWharf_flavor: A warship berths here between battles. Any city on the Nile ought to have at least a couple of defensive ships at the ready.
Buildings/#WarshipWharf_sailingship: Our warship is out in battle.
Buildings/#Courthouse_tooltip: Reduces crime. Holds part of your treasury
Buildings/#Courthouse_flavor: Courthouses send forth magistrates, who help to reduce crime by ensuring that all grievances get a fair hearing. Courthouse vaults hold part of your city's treasury.
Buildings/#Courthouse_workers_0: This Courthouse has no workers at all, so local citizens solve their own disputes in whatever ways they can.
Buildings/#Courthouse_workers_1: There are so few magistrates available that legal decisions seem almost random to the plaintiffs.
Buildings/#Courthouse_workers_50: With only half the workers it needs, this Courthouse sometimes rushes to judgment.
Buildings/#Courthouse_workers_75: Because it is slightly understaffed, this Courthouse has a small backlog of cases to hear.
Buildings/#Courthouse_workers_100: The Courthouse has all the staff it needs to hear citizens' complaints swiftly and dispatch careful decisions.
Buildings/#Courthouse_Magistrate_Out: The magistrate is out resolving disputes.
Buildings/#Courthouse_Magistrate_In: The magistrate is in his chambers.
Buildings/#Farm_Nextflood: The next floods will come in {[Month]}.
Buildings/#Farm_Nile_empty: This farm needs laborers, who can be trained at a Work Camp.
Buildings/#Farm_Nile_staffed: This farm has a full crew of laborers working the fields.
Buildings/#Brickworks_tooltip: Produces bricks <sprite name="Bricks"> from clay <sprite name="Clay"> and straw <sprite name="Straw">
Buildings/#Brickworks_flavor: Clay and straw are combined here to form sturdy, durable bricks.
Buildings/#Brickworks_disabled: Your Overseer of Commerce ordered a halt to brick production.
Buildings/#Brickworks_workers_0: This Brickworks has no employees. Not a single brick can be made.
Buildings/#Brickworks_workers_100: This workshop has all the employees it needs. It produces tons of bricks.

Buildings/#OsirisTempleComplex_tooltip: This gigantic temple can only be built once, and for one god only. Greatly improves Osiris' mood
Buildings/#RaTempleComplex_tooltip: This gigantic temple can only be built once, and for one god only. Greatly improves Ra's mood
Buildings/#PtahTempleComplex_tooltip: This gigantic temple can only be built once, and for one god only. Greatly improves Ptah's mood
Buildings/#SethTempleComplex_tooltip: This gigantic temple can only be built once, and for one god only. Greatly improves Seth's mood
Buildings/#BastTempleComplex_tooltip: This gigantic temple can only be built once, and for one god only. Greatly improves Bast's mood
Buildings/#OsirisTempleComplex_flavor: Osiris is the god of the Nile flood, and all life which springs from the underworld. With his benevolence, your city may receive the blessing of a bountiful annual Inundation, bringing life-giving fertile soil to your fields. He can also improve the yield at harvest time in other ways. An Altar of Sebek - god of fertility - means that priests of Osiris can help your citizens stretch their food and other supplies a little further, while an Oracle of Min - god of regeneration - infuses the wildlife in and around your city with greater vitality. His Oracle makes animal herds and fish colonies more resilient, and even accelerates the regrowth of some plants.
Buildings/#RaTempleComplex_flavor: As god of the Kingdom, Ra facilitates trade and travel throughout the known world, and can even help to bolster your reputation throughout Egypt. An Altar of Ma'at - goddess of justice - helps prevent crime in your city, while an Oracle of Horus - god of the Pharaoh - makes your employees more willing to attend to their daily labors. In the name of Pharaoh, they'll be inspired to work for the greater good of Egypt.
Buildings/#PtahTempleComplex_flavor: Ptah is the patron god of craftsmen, and helps many of them finish their tasks more quickly. An Altar of Amon - god of the Sun - improves your city's ability to build monuments, while an Oracle of Thoth - god of wisdom and learning - can facilitate the education of your people.
Buildings/#SethTempleComplex_flavor: When Seth is appeased, your enemies are his enemies. He can help your greenest soldiers fight like seasoned veterans, and even strike down your enemies by his own hand. So powerful is he that his influence even extends to battles fought far afield. An Altar of Anubis - God of Death - makes Mortuaries need less linen to prepare bodies for eternity while an Oracle of Sekhmet - Goddess of War - endows priests of Seth with the power to reduce the risk of crime in the houses that they pass and to apprehend criminals in the city.
Buildings/#BastTempleComplex_flavor: As goddess of the home, Bast can improve the quality of life in your city, and can allow your citizens to enjoy a much higher standard of living than might otherwise be the case. So great is her power that she can even help keep the other gods happy. Of course, if she is unappeased, then your city will know true misery and suffering. An Altar of Isis - goddess of healing - can help ensure that your citizens remain in good health, and even assist them if they do get sick, while an Oracle of Hathor - goddess of joy, love and festivity - can help keep your people a little happier in spite of whatever problems they might have.

Encyclo/#Granary_Content:
Because farming was largely impossible during the Inundation, granaries were vitally important to ensure that the ancient Egyptians were fed year-round. Granaries not only stored grain and other foods, but also manufactured flour.  
The granary evolved over time. In the Archaic period, the Egyptian granary was shaped like a cone with a domed top. They were made from wood or brick, and the largest ones had ladders or steps leading to the filling hole. In the Middle Kingdom, the granary was shaped like a quadrangle and had a flat roof with several filling holes, like those depicted in our game. A third type of granary was used only for seed to be sown during the next growing season. These granaries were shaped like a trapezoid, a distinctly different shape than granaries used for food storage, so that the seed grain would not be eaten by mistake. 
Most granaries were strictly maintained by the government. Soldiers, construction workers and other non-agricultural workers all ate from these granaries. Some wealthy private citizens had their own granaries, and some peasants had their own small granaries to store whatever part of the harvest they were allowed to keep.
Encyclo/#StorageYard_Content:
In ancient Egypt, there were storage magazines in both the temple and the palace for state goods. These would have been roofed structures, and mostly everything would have been stored in large pottery vessels. Open-air storage facilities in the middle of the city was unlikely. There was the occasional rain storm, but also the flood could be dangerous and there would be the occasional flash flood which would be detrimental to towns. They were well supervised by scribes who kept strict track of the inventory. 
The design of the storage yard in the game thus does not reflect the reality, this choice was made to allow the player to quickly see what's in stock at any moment in time.
Encyclo/#Farming_Content:
Farming and agriculture were the basis of the Egyptian economy. Abundant crops allowed Egypt to <link="#Trade_Title"><u>trade</u></link> with neighbors, bringing new goods into Egypt. 
The key to successful farming was the Inundation, in the season called akhet. Every year, the Nile flooded its banks, re-fertilizing the soil. As long as the Inundation occurred, the Egyptians could count on having plenty of food to eat. In years of low or no Inundation, famine struck Egypt, which was sometimes enough to topple governments. 
To take advantage of the restoring Inundation, dykes were built around farms to capture the water as it rose. As the Nile receded (the season called peret), the water, along with its nutrients, slowly soaked into the soil. After about six weeks, the farmer opened the dykes and let the rest of the water drain out. Of course, being submerged in water made the ground quite soft. Before he could sow his seed, the farmer had to wait for the land to dry out a little and become firm. 
Finally, during the season of shemu, the crops were harvested. Crops meant for Egyptian consumption were stored in <link="#Granary_Title"><u>granaries</u></link>. Food for export was stored in <link="#StorageYard_Title"><u>Storage Yards</u></link> until it could be loaded onto barges. 
Government-owned farms and farms owned by Estate owners employed laborers to do many of the most arduous tasks on the land. Farming was not easy work, and much of the work was done by hand. The tools farmers had at their disposal included the hoe, the hand-held plough, and the sickle. Domesticated oxen eased some of the plowing. 
Farming produced both raw materials and foodstuffs. <link="#Grain_Title"><u>Grain & Barley</u></link> were key food crops, and <link="#Flax_Title"><u>flax</u></link>, which was manufactured into <link="#Linen_Title"><u>linen</u></link>, was the most important raw material crop. 
Farming and agriculture were also integral to the Egyptian afterlife. Once the deceased has been granted entry into the afterlife, he finds himself working the soil in the Field of Reeds.
Encyclo/#Industry_Content:
By the Old Kingdom, manufacture of products had moved out of the domestic setting and into centralized workshops which turned out nearly all the supplies needed for daily life. Each workshop specialized in a particular product and operated very much like a modern assembly line. Each worker was responsible for a particular aspect of the finished product, rather than working on an item from beginning to end. The tools the artisans used in these workshops were the property of the state, as were any materials the workshops produced. Craftsmen earned wages, usually paid in food and necessary goods. 
Egyptian industry thrived and produced many products. Egyptians could find employment as <link="#Pottery_Title"><u>potters</u></link>, <link="#Linen_Title"><u>weavers</u></link>, <link="#Jewelry_Title"><u>jewelers</u></link>, tanners, <link="#Carpenters_Title"><u>carpenters</u></link> and smelters as well as bakers and <link="#Beer_Title"><u>brewers</u></link>.
Encyclo/#Housing_Content:
Egyptians made their homes from brick, wood, mud or occasionally stone. Housing style and size depended upon the wealth of the citizen and where they lived. Thus, rural citizens who farmed for a living resided in simple brick or pressed mud structures of two to four rooms. City homes of the working class were likewise small, and some two-story, two-family homes were built to save space in the most crowded cities. City-dwelling workers lived in brick homes of maybe 3 to 5 rooms. 
Wealthier citizens had larger homes, and some of these were quite spacious. Senior government officials had estates that included large-scale houses, gardens, associated workshops, private granaries, and houses for servants. The most luxurious homes of all were the <link="#PharaohsHome_Title"><u>Pharaoh's palaces</u></link>.  
For the most part, Egyptian cities grew organically in whichever direction they could. A few cities, however, were planned, most notably the settlement built for workers at Deir el-Medina. 
Most Egyptian cities were surrounded by walls. For more on defensive structures, click <link="#Defenses_Title"><u>here</u></link>.
Encyclo/#Roads_Content:
The <link="#Nile_Title"><u>Nile</u></link> was Egypt's main highway. Boats of all shapes and sizes transported people, goods and materials from one point to another. The ancient Egyptians, of course, had land-based roads as well. These roads were generally not paved in any fashion but were simply well-worn paths. In most cities, roads twisted and turned in any way necessary. In planned cities, such as the settlement for workers at Deir el-Medina, the roads were laid out in a neat grid. 
Some trade routes were also well-established, but these roads weren't paved, either - and they could be quite dangerous to traverse. For more on the perils of successful trade, click <link="#Trade_Title"><u>here</u></link>.
Encyclo/#Irrigation_Content:
The Egyptians increased the amount of arable land through irrigation. Egyptians began to build a network of irrigation canals and ditches as early as the ninth dynasty, or about 2000 BC. Some canals seem to have existed before then, but they were used for transportation. The irrigation canals extended the benefits of the river, bringing nourishing silt to areas away from the river. 
Early in Egyptian history, farmers who wanted to irrigate their land had a tough time of it. Farmers irrigated their land by hand, carrying a yoke with two buckets made of clay or leather to the Nile or some other water source. The farmer returned with his buckets of water to his farm, which was subdivided by small dykes. The dykes captured the water, maximizing the benefit of this slow and arduous method of irrigation.  
At the beginning of the 18th dynasty (about 1300 BC), the water lift, or shaduf, was introduced. The shaduf probably came to Egypt from Mesopotamia, where it had been in use as early as 2370 BC. Positioned on the bank of the Nile or other water source, the shaduf was made from a long wooden beam that rocked back and forth on a pivot. A bucket at one end of the beam was counterbalanced with a brick or other weight. A person pushed down on the end with the bucket to dip it into the water, and the brick helped the worker lift the water into the gully that was attached to the shaduf. 
The introduction of the shaduf increased the arable land in Egypt by about 15 percent. Also, because it was never submerged under water, land irrigated by the shaduf could produce two harvests a year instead of one.
Encyclo/#Labor_Content:
Peasants performed most of the hard labor in ancient Egypt. Peasants tilled the soil and harvested the crops during the growing season. During the Inundation, these same workers were conscripted to do work for the state. They mostly worked to build pyramids and other structures, but these workers could also be tasked with maintaining the Egyptian infrastructure, like <link="#Roads_Title"><u>roads</u></link> and <link="#Irrigation_Title"><u>irrigation ditches</u></link>. 
While the work the peasants performed wasn't easy, they received fair treatment and benefits from the government. The typical workday lasted eight hours with a break at lunch. The work week lasted eight days, with two days off at the end. In addition to these 'weekends,' work stopped for festivals. Workers could also take time off if there was sickness or death in the family. 
Attendance was very well documented, as were the reasons for missing work. Some reasons for missing work probably wouldn't be acceptable excuses today. According to an absentee record discovered at Deir el-Medina, one worker missed work to go drinking with a buddy. 
Despite what many people think, slave labor was seldom used on state construction projects. Sometimes, slaves were used in quarries, but for the most part, they served in households. 
If workers were not treated well, they could go on strike. During Ramses III's reign, about 1152 BC, workers at Deir el-Medina formally stopped work to protest the delay of their compensation. Their strike was successful, and the problem of late compensation was rectified.
Encyclo/#Water_Content:
Getting drinking water to the populace was a bit of a challenge in ancient Egypt. The main water source was the Nile and the Nile's water table. Away from the Nile, there were a few oases, but most of the land was arid. 
To get water to neighborhoods, cisterns were built in well-to-do houses. Water carriers brought buckets full of water to these houses, and emptied them into the cisterns. 
The Egyptians were adept at digging wells. Workers had to dig through 300 feet of rock for one well near the worker's settlement at Giza. Most wells had a well house capping them. From the well house, stairs wound down to the water's level. From there, people could fill their jugs with water.
Encyclo/#Nile_Content:
Egyptian civilization simply would not exist without the Nile. In a region where rain is scarce, the Nile provides a reliable source of water to both the people and the land. By flooding its banks on a relatively predictable basis, the Nile also refertilizes farmland. 
The importance of the Nile was not lost on the ancient Egyptians. Watching the Nile continuously bring the land back to life contributed volumes to Egyptian religious customs, particularly their belief in an afterlife.  
The Egyptian calendar was divided into seasons named for the different stages of the Nile. The Inundation, when the Nile was flooding its banks, was called akhet. The Inundation occurred because of yearly monsoons at the source of the Blue Nile on the Ethiopian plateaus. The Emergence, or peret, marked the time when the Nile receded and the land began to emerge. Harvest time was called shemu, sometimes translated as drought.
Encyclo/#Dentistry_Content:
Dentistry was one of many fields that an ancient Egyptian doctor could practice. Remains of ancient Egyptians indicate that dentists were fighting an uphill battle. Tooth decay was promoted by omnipresent sand. Sand worked its way into everything, including food, and constantly crunching on sand quickly wore down the Egyptians' teeth. Tooth wear often led to abscesses, which could cause the tooth to fall out and could even cause death. 
Medical papyri detail the actions dentists took to treat specific problems. For example, if a tooth fell out, the dentist bound the tooth to a neighboring tooth with gold or silver wire. There is even a recipe for fillings, involving mixing resin and malachite, but archaeologists have found no remains of teeth with the fillings still intact. 
Archeologists have uncovered tools that they believe were used as toothbrushes. Thus far, no discoveries of ancient Egyptian floss have been reported.
Encyclo/#Apothecary_Content:
Ancient Egyptian medicinal and pharmaceutical practices are well-documented. Religion was instrumental in curing disease, and most prescribed cures were accompanied by prayers or spells. Medical papyri outlined specific cures, some of which seem a bit unusual by our standards. 
To cure indigestion, for instance, a hog's tooth was crushed and placed inside of four sugar cakes. The patient was to eat one of these cakes per day, after which time the indigestion should be cured. 
A cure for baldness called for a mixture of a rook's vertebra, a burnt donkey's hoof and the lard of a black snake.
Encyclo/#Medicine_Content:
Like other parts of Egyptian society, the medical profession was highly segmented and bureaucratic. The profession was organized along hierarchical lines, with doctors holding titles such as senior doctor, inspector, overseer and master of physicians. The highest-ranking doctor was the 'Chief of Physicians of the South and North.' 
Doctors gained their medical knowledge through studying the internal organs of animals and texts, not through observing the embalming process. Medicine was distinctly separate from the funerary rites. 
Good health was anchored in the concept of metu, or channels. The heart was the center of the body, and all parts of the body were linked to the heart by metu. More than a description of the circulatory system, all systems of the body were considered to be metu. Illness occurred when some part of the metu was blocked. 
To cure illnesses, doctors prescribed medicine combined with prayer. For more on Egyptian pharmaceutical practices, see <link="#Apothecary_Title"><u>apothecaries</u></link>. 
Egyptians suffered from polio, smallpox, tuberculosis of the spine and malaria, among other maladies. The Egyptians were also prone to illness caused by parasitic worms.
Encyclo/#Embalmers_Content:
Embalming is the cornerstone of ancient Egyptian funerary customs. The ka, or spirit, of the deceased needed a place to live in the afterlife and, thus, needed its body. During the embalming process, the body was first rinsed in the waters of the Nile, symbolizing rebirth. Then, internal organs were removed from the corpse and stored in containers called canopic jars. The only organ that was discarded was the brain (which was removed through the nose) because the ancient Egyptians believed that it served no purpose. The canopic jars were entombed with the body. 
After removing the internal organs, the embalmer filled the body cavity with perfumes, oils, and linen and closed the body up. Then, the body was covered in natron, a type of salt. After 70 days, the body was rinsed off, wrapped in linen and smeared with bitumen. The bitumen helped to kill bacteria and fungi that would otherwise work to decompose the body. 
Because of the expense of the embalming process, only the wealthiest citizens were able to afford it.
Encyclo/#Temples_Content:
Temples were viewed as the residences of the gods, and each temple had scores of attending <link="#Priests_Title"><u>priests</u></link> to care for the god. Citizens took part in the care of the gods through offerings, but they rarely saw the statue of the god hidden deep inside the temple. Only on feast days, when the god was carried through town on a ceremonial bark, did citizens actually catch a glimpse of the deity, though the deity was still hidden within a portable shrine.
Egyptians turned to the gods for advice.
